title: 108_s898
content: The Act is titled the "Fern Lake Conservation and Recreation Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purposes. The Congress finds that Fern Lake and its surrounding watershed in Bell County, Kentucky, and Claiborne County, Tennessee, are potential additions to Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. Acquiring Fern Lake and its watershed would protect the vista from Pinnacle Overlook, enhance recreational opportunities, and safeguard the water supply for the City of Middlesboro, Kentucky. The 4,500-acre Fern Lake watershed is currently privately owned. The 4,500-acre Fern Lake watershed, including the 150-acre lake, is privately owned and currently for sale. The Secretary of the Interior is unable to use appropriated funds to acquire the lands. The Act aims to authorize the use of funds to acquire Fern Lake and its surrounding watershed to protect scenic and natural resources at Cumberland Gap National Historical Park and ensure a safe water supply for the City of Middlesboro, Kentucky. The Act authorizes the use of funds to acquire Fern Lake and its surrounding watershed to protect scenic and natural resources at Cumberland Gap National Historical Park and ensure a safe water supply for the City of Middlesboro, Kentucky. The Secretary, through the Director of the National Park Service, is authorized to acquire approximately 4,500 acres of land, including Fern Lake and its surrounding watershed, to add to Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land, including Fern Lake and its watershed, to add to Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. The boundaries of the park will be revised to include the acquired land, which will be administered according to park regulations. If Fern Lake is acquired, it will be conveyed to the city of Middlesboro, Kentucky. The Secretary is authorized to acquire Fern Lake and its watershed to add to Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. Fern Lake, along with the dam and water withdrawal infrastructure, will be conveyed to the city of Middlesboro, Kentucky. The Secretary may retain an easement for scenic and recreational purposes. If Fern Lake is no longer used for municipal water supply, ownership will revert to the United States for park management. To provide water for municipal needs and create new recreational opportunities at the park, the Secretary must consult with officials in Kentucky, Tennessee, and Virginia, tourism organizations in these states, and other interested parties.
